bug.author: edilinux
bug.summary: Tesseract 4.0.0 crashed on Intel I5-8400 CPU with Debian 9.6.0 amd64 (SSE/AVX/AVX2)
bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h3>Environment</denchmark-h>
Tesseract Version: 4.0.0 Release Commit Number: 5131699 Platform: Debian 9.6.0 amd64
<denchmark-h:h3>Current Behavior: Tesseract 4.0.0 crashed on Itel I5-8400 CPU with Debian 9.6.0 amd64 (SSE/AVX/AVX2).</denchmark-h>
I compiled the tesseract 4.0 on Itel I5-8400 CPU with Debian 9.6.0 amd64. tesseract --version output this: tesseract 4.0.0 leptonica-1.74.2 libjpeg 6b (libjpeg-turbo 1.5.1) : libpng 1.6.28 : libtiff 4.0.8 : zlib 1.2.8 Found AVX2 Found AVX Found SSE When I call tesseract several times, crash happens and PC is reboot. I have a Intel G4650 CPU and this CPU not suport AVX2 / AVX and everything works fine! Never crash happens! How to make tesseract work fine on Intel I5-8400 with AVX/AVX2/SSE. <denchmark-h:h3>Expected Behavior:</denchmark-h>
<denchmark-h:h3>Suggested Fix:</denchmark-h>

As you compile Tesseract yourself, you could locally modify <denchmark-link:https://github.com/tesseract-ocr/tesseract/blob/master/src/arch/simddetect.cpp#L58>the code</denchmark-link> to pretend that your CPU does not support AVX2 by setting . Does that help? If yes, we must examine that closer. If not, you also have to set . But there is another more fundamental problem: user code like Tesseract should never cause a Linux system crash. Can you reproduce the crash with the official <denchmark-link:https://packages.debian.org/search?keywords=tesseract-ocr&searchon=names&exact=1&suite=all&section=all>Debian tesseract-ocr package 4.0.0</denchmark-link> (from stretch-backports or newer)? Then I'd report an issue to Debian.

I assume that Tesseract does not crash when you just run tesseract -v several times, but crashes while doing real OCR. Does it crash with any image? How often do you have to run it until it crashes with a small image? Does it crash faster when doing OCR of a large image? Do you get any crash information, either a short message on the screen or messages in /var/log/syslog? Recently I noticed that the Tesseract code uses AVX(2) with a wrong alignment of data (4-byte aligned instead of 8-byte aligned). That might explain performance problems (especially observed on Windows, but also on Linux). I could not examine it closer up to now, but perhaps such misaligned data causes a kernel trap causing a system reboot in rare cases (that's pure speculation up to now).

Thank you for reporting those new test results. That's very interesting and adds more hints that there might be a problem with Tesseract's implementation of the dot product calculation on AVX2.
